Watson Gordon’s is too much of the mere clergyman—is a pleasant likeness, and has the shape of his mouth, and the setting of his feet very good. Duncan’s is a work of genius, and is the giant look- ing up, awalrening, but not awakened—it is avery fine picture. Mr. Hill’s Calotypes we like better than all the rest3 because what in them is true, is absolutely so, and they have some delicate render- ings which are all but beyond the power of any human artist ; for though man’s art is mighty, nature’s is mightier.
